This week was spring harvest at the school gardens. Thanks to Mike and Julia’s help, we donated 389 bunches of produce (lettuce, kale, bok choy, spinach, radishes, chives, oregano, thyme) to the school nutrition department which will be shared with community members at Friday’s meal pickup sites. Soon the gardens will be planted with the next round of crops for flexible use (community share, summer/fall learning, etc.) depending on what circumstances dictate.

We’re so thankful to be able to continue to use the gardens for teaching, learning, and community connections during this time!

Jen, School Gardens Coordinator

post_text: The ARMS Social Studies department is keeping students connected to each other and larger social issues during this time of distancing. Ms. Cocco's 8th grade Civics students had a virtual visit with Mandi Jo Hanneke, Amherst Town Councilor, on May 15. Students asked questions about their independent action projects, ranging from CO2 emissions to trans rights. They also asked questions related to COVID and the town/schools' reopening. Ms. Hanneke was a wonderful resource. As a consequence, State Rep. Mindy Domb has reached out to offer to speak to ARMS students about their COVID concerns on June 5. The Civics learning continued on May 22 with Amherst resident and recent college grad Hattie Wilder-Karlstrom giving a virtual assembly to over 75 8th graders about her experiences giving humanitarian aid at the US-Mexico border. Great job students continuing to stay curious and engaged! S/O to the ARMS Social Studies Department!

March 15, 2020

Dear ARPS Families:

This evening, Massachusetts Governor Charlie Baker announced that all schools in Massachusetts will be closed for a three week period, with the earliest possible opening of school on Tuesday, April 7. This is one of many steps he outlined in response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the need for social distancing. Massachusetts Commissioner of Education Jeffrey Riley will be providing Superintendents with more information this week, and we will keep the ARPS community updated continuously as information becomes available.

Sincerely, Michael Morris, Superintendent

A Letter From the Athletics Director:

Good Evening Coaches,

The MIAA Board of Directors met this afternoon in regards to outbreak of COVID-19. In conclusion the Board of Directors decision is to delay the start of the 2020 spring season to March 30th.

The following guidelines must be followed during this delayed start time:

- Out of season coaching is not allowed during this period (no coaches can attend captains practices)
- The start date for first competition will be consistent with MIAA Handbook Rule 35.4.1
-The first team competition may not occur before the 11th calendar day after and including the first day of practice

Please let me know if you have any questions.

Thanks,

Victoria

Beginning this spring, Amherst College student-athletes and Fort River Elementary School students, grades K-6, are teaming up as partners during recess. The partnership is intended to foster community connection and provide modeling for play.

Roughly thirty Amherst College student-athletes, representing a variety of sports, began their visits after winter break and will continue to visit weekly throughout the rest of the semester. The student-athletes represent women's and men's cross country, football, field hockey, women's and men's ice hockey, women's and men's lacrosse, women's and men's squash, women's and men's soccer, women's and men's track and field, and volleyball.

Early reports from the Amherst student-athletes and the Fort River students have been very positive, with the most excitement around playing football and soccer, swinging on the swings, and just enjoying spending time together.

We are excited to announce some new opportunities for bilingual students. Clubs, Cafes, and Art all provided through the MA Seal of Biliteracy Pathway Awards that we received for the first time this year! As a district we value the linguistic diversity of our community and through this initiative we will be able to celebrate the assets of multilingualism and to promote sustained English language, native language, heritage language, and global language learning.

You can find more information about the program and links to more resources at arps.org/sealofbiliteracy.
